NTCP overexpression in cell lines that are not permissive for HBV infection rendered them susceptible. however, the efficiency of the infection remained intriguingly low. this strongly suggests that plasma membrane receptors are not the only limiting factors of infection. viral particles enter early endosomes that progress to late endosomes. acidification does not appear to be an essential factor for HBV infection. trafficking through endosomes may only represent an intermediate step leading to a cellular organelle where the viral genome is released. the disulfide bond-reducing activity of the endocytic pathway is activated upon internalization of a folate-FRET reporter into endosomes. this activity requires deprotonation of thiols, which is not favored thermodynamically by the acidic environment of the endosome. this suggests that most likely, an enzymatic catalysis is involved. viral particles were found dispersed into a fraction of heterogeneous endocytic vesicles consisting of early and late endosomes. they later were concentrated into lysosomes, suggesting that viral nucleocapsids remain intact in the endocytic pathway for at least several days. this is consistent with the observation made during the first characterization of the HepaRG cell line, showing that the input viral particle level is relatively stable. ative branch appears to be a dead-end pathway, possibly as a part of the cell defense mechanisms to limit the number of viral particles available to initiate productive infection. lysosomal trafficking and accumulation of the viral particles in this compartment are contributing factors to the unusual low efficiency of HBV infection in vitro.
